articles.headline: U.S. Sees Much to Fear in a Hostile Russia
articles.snippet: Washington worries that an emboldened but estranged Moscow could use its arms industry and influence to undermine U.S. interests.
articles.abstract: Washington worries that an emboldened but estranged Moscow could use its arms industry and influence to undermine U.S. interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: The president of Syria spent two days this week in Russia with a shopping list of sophisticated weapons he wanted to buy. The visit may prove a worrisome preview of things to come.

articles.headline: Olympics Are Ratings Bonanza for Chinese TV
articles.snippet: The broadcast of the Beijing Olympic Games has been a boon for China Central Television, one of the chief propaganda arms of the state and perhaps a new global media titan.
articles.abstract: The broadcast of the Beijing Olympic Games has been a boon for China Central Television, one of the chief propaganda arms of the state and perhaps a new global media titan.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  When the Beijing Olympic Games kicked off two weeks ago with a four-hour spectacular, more than 840 million people in China tuned in, perhaps the largest television audience in history for a single event.

articles.headline: Profit Without Risk? Not Likely
articles.snippet: During the credit boom that preceded the current bust, many professional investors thought that they had found a way to increase their profits without taking on risk.
articles.abstract: During the credit boom that preceded the current bust, many professional investors thought that they had found a way to increase their profits without taking on risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of the credit boom that preceded the current bust was the belief of professional investors that they had found a way to increase their profits without taking on risk.

articles.headline: Iraq Takes Aim at U.S.-Tied Sunni Groups’ Leaders
articles.snippet: Iraq’s Shiite-dominated government is driving out many leaders of Sunni citizen patrols, which have been a major pillar in the decline in violence.
articles.abstract: Iraq’s Shiite-dominated government is driving out many leaders of Sunni citizen patrols, which have been a major pillar in the decline in violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The Shiite-dominated government in Iraq is driving out many leaders of Sunni citizen patrols, the groups of former insurgents who joined the American payroll and have been a major pillar in the decline in violence around the nation.

articles.headline: Burdened by Mortgages, Lehman’s Options Narrow
articles.snippet: As the stocks of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have plummeted, financial shares have taken a beating. But few have suffered as much as Lehman Brothers.
articles.abstract: As the stocks of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have plummeted, financial shares have taken a beating. But few have suffered as much as Lehman Brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the stocks of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have plummeted, financial shares have taken a beating. But few have suffered as much as Lehman Brothers, the troubled investment bank whose stock plunged more than 10 percent on 11 days of the last quarter.

articles.headline: Some Fear Commercial Property Loans Will Be Next Stage in Downturn
articles.snippet: As the value of home mortgages crumbles by the day, some bankers are worried that commercial real estate loans will be affected next.
articles.abstract: As the value of home mortgages crumbles by the day, some bankers are worried that commercial real estate loans will be affected next.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the value of home mortgages crumbles by the day, Wall Street has hoped that commercial real estate loans would stay clear of the storm.

articles.headline: Smartphone Start-Ups Have a Friend in This Fund
articles.snippet: A new $100 million fund invests in start-ups specializing in iPhone applications.
articles.abstract: A new $100 million fund invests in start-ups specializing in iPhone applications.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif.  Matt Murphy eats at expensive steakhouses, likes to watch his kids play soccer and is a loyal fan of Peet’s Coffee and Tea. And if he has his way, mobile phone users will know as much about each other as readers now know about him.

articles.headline: Obama and McCain Seek a Common Touch
articles.snippet: Convinced that financially pinched voters might hold the electoral key in November, the candidates chose an unlikely strategy that drew attention to their own wealth.
articles.abstract: Convinced that financially pinched voters might hold the electoral key in November, the candidates chose an unlikely strategy that drew attention to their own wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama and John McCain ripped into each other on Thursday over how many houses, fireplaces and even wine cellars they own, using allusions to net worth to deride each other while portraying themselves as able helmsmen for a faltering economy.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Katharine Q. Seelye
